rules.name: Cardiac Emergency
rules.description: Possible cardiac emergency. Chest pain combined with breathing difficulty may indicate a heart attack.
actions: Call 108 immediately
Sit upright, do not lie flat
Loosen tight clothing
Chew an aspirin if available and not allergic
Do NOT move the patient unnecessarily
Stay calm and wait for help

rules.name: Cardiac Event - Chest Pain Alone
rules.description: Chest pain alone can indicate a serious cardiac event. Treat as emergency until proven otherwise.
actions: Call 108 immediately
Sit upright and rest
Chew an aspirin if available and not allergic
Loosen tight clothing
Monitor breathing

rules.name: Unconscious Person
rules.description: An unconscious person needs immediate emergency care. Check for breathing and pulse.
actions: Call 108 immediately
Check if the person is breathing
If not breathing, begin CPR
If breathing, place in recovery position
Do NOT give food or water
Do NOT leave the person alone

rules.name: Severe Hemorrhage
rules.description: Severe bleeding can lead to shock and death if not controlled quickly.
actions: Call 108 immediately
Apply firm direct pressure using a clean cloth
Do NOT remove the cloth — add more layers
Elevate the injured limb if possible
Apply a tourniquet only as last resort above the wound
Keep the patient lying down and warm

rules.name: Stroke
rules.description: Stroke is a time-critical emergency. Use FAST: Face drooping, Arm weakness, Speech difficulty, Time to call emergency.
actions: Call 108 immediately — every minute counts
Note the time symptoms started
Do NOT give food or water
Keep the patient comfortable and still
If unconscious, place in recovery position
Do NOT give aspirin for stroke

rules.name: Choking Emergency
rules.description: Airway obstruction can be fatal in minutes. Immediate action required.
actions: If conscious, perform Heimlich manoeuvre (abdominal thrusts)
Stand behind the person, fist above navel, thrust inward and upward
For infants: 5 back blows then 5 chest thrusts
If unconscious, call 108 and begin CPR
Check mouth for visible objects
Do NOT do a blind finger sweep

rules.name: Spinal Injury
rules.description: Suspected spinal injury — do NOT move the patient. Improper movement can cause permanent paralysis.
actions: Call 108 immediately
Do NOT move the patient
Keep the head, neck and spine aligned
Stabilize the head with your hands
Monitor breathing
Cover with blanket to prevent shock

rules.name: Drowning
rules.description: Drowning victim needs immediate resuscitation. Every second counts.
actions: Call 108 immediately
Remove from water safely
Check for breathing
If not breathing, begin rescue breaths and CPR
Place in recovery position if breathing
Keep warm — remove wet clothing

rules.name: Meningitis Suspicion
rules.description: High fever with stiff neck may indicate meningitis — a life-threatening infection.
actions: Call 108 immediately
Keep the patient in a dark, quiet room
Do NOT give food or water if consciousness is altered
Monitor breathing and consciousness
Note all symptoms and time of onset

rules.name: Seizure
rules.description: Most seizures stop on their own. Protect the patient from injury during the seizure.
actions: Clear area of dangerous objects
Do NOT restrain the person
Do NOT put anything in the mouth
Time the seizure
Place on side after seizure stops
Call 108 if seizure lasts more than 5 minutes
Stay with the patient until fully conscious

rules.name: Severe Allergic Reaction
rules.description: Anaphylaxis can cause airway closure and death within minutes.
actions: Call 108 immediately
Use EpiPen if available (inject into outer thigh)
Lay the patient flat with legs elevated
If breathing difficulty, sit them upright
Loosen tight clothing
Be ready to perform CPR

rules.name: Poisoning
rules.description: Poisoning requires immediate medical attention. Identify the substance if possible.
actions: Call 108 and Poison Control
Do NOT induce vomiting unless directed
If chemical on skin, remove clothing and rinse with water
Keep a sample of the poison/container
Monitor breathing and consciousness
If unconscious, place in recovery position

rules.name: Snake Bite
rules.description: Snake bites need anti-venom treatment at a hospital. Do NOT cut, suck, or apply tourniquet.
actions: Call 108 immediately
Keep the patient still and calm
Remove rings/watches before swelling
Immobilize the bitten limb below heart level
Wrap with pressure bandage (NOT tight tourniquet)
Do NOT cut the wound or suck venom
Try to remember the snake's appearance

rules.name: Severe Burns
rules.description: Severe burns need professional medical care. Cool the burn but do not apply ice.
actions: Call 108 for large or deep burns
Cool with running water for 20 minutes
Do NOT apply ice, butter, or toothpaste
Cover loosely with clean, non-stick dressing
Remove jewelry near the burn before swelling
Give small sips of water if conscious
Watch for signs of shock

rules.name: Head Injury
rules.description: Head injuries can have delayed serious effects. Monitor closely.
actions: Call 108 if unconscious or confused
Keep the patient still
Apply gentle pressure with clean cloth if bleeding
Monitor for vomiting, confusion, or drowsiness
Do NOT give food or water
Do NOT let the person sleep for first few hours
Watch for unequal pupil size

rules.name: Heat Stroke
rules.description: Heat stroke is a medical emergency. Body temperature exceeds 40°C.
actions: Call 108 immediately
Move to shade or cool area
Remove excess clothing
Cool with water, wet towels, or fanning
Apply ice packs to neck, armpits, groin
Give small sips of cool water if conscious
Do NOT give fever medicine

rules.name: Electric Shock
rules.description: Electrical injuries can cause cardiac arrest and internal burns.
actions: Do NOT touch the person if still near power source
Turn off power or use non-conductive material to separate
Call 108 immediately
Check breathing and pulse
Begin CPR if needed
Treat visible burns with cool water
Watch for delayed cardiac effects

rules.name: Diabetic Emergency
rules.description: Diabetic emergencies can lead to coma. Low sugar is more immediately dangerous.
actions: If conscious and able to swallow, give sugar/juice/candy
If unconscious, do NOT give food or water
Call 108 if no improvement in 10 minutes
Place unconscious patient in recovery position
Check for medical ID bracelet
Monitor breathing

rules.name: Severe Asthma Attack
rules.description: Severe asthma attack with no relief from inhaler needs emergency care.
actions: Help patient sit upright
Use reliever inhaler (blue) — 4 puffs
Wait 4 minutes, give 4 more puffs if no relief
Call 108 if no improvement
Keep the patient calm
Loosen tight clothing
Do NOT force the patient to lie down

rules.name: Pregnancy Emergency
rules.description: Pregnancy emergencies need immediate professional care.
actions: Call 108 immediately
Keep the person comfortable on left side
Do NOT try to stop natural labor
If bleeding, use clean pads but do NOT insert anything
Time contractions
Keep warm and calm

rules.name: Vomiting Blood
rules.description: Vomiting blood indicates serious internal bleeding and requires emergency care.
actions: Call 108 immediately
Keep the patient on their side
Do NOT give food or water
Save a sample of vomit for doctors
Monitor for shock (pale, cold, rapid pulse)
Keep warm and still

rules.name: Hypothermia
rules.description: Hypothermia can be fatal. Warm gradually — do NOT use direct heat.
actions: Move to warm shelter
Remove wet clothing
Wrap in blankets/warm clothing
Give warm sweet drinks if conscious
Do NOT apply direct heat (hot water, fire)
Do NOT rub the skin
Call 108 if severe or unconscious

rules.name: Fracture
rules.description: Suspected fractures need immobilization and professional care.
actions: Do NOT move the injured limb
Immobilize with splint or padded support
Apply ice pack wrapped in cloth
Elevate if possible
Go to nearest hospital
Give pain relief if available

rules.name: Severe Abdominal Pain
rules.description: Severe abdominal pain may indicate appendicitis, obstruction, or other surgical emergency.
actions: Do NOT give food or water
Do NOT give painkillers before medical exam
Rest in comfortable position
Call 108 or go to hospital
Monitor for fever or vomiting
Note when pain started and location

rules.name: Insect/Animal Bite
rules.description: Most bites are not life-threatening, but monitor for allergic reactions.
actions: Wash the bite area with soap and water
Apply cold compress
Watch for allergic reactions (swelling, breathing difficulty)
For dog bites: seek anti-rabies treatment
For scorpion stings: seek medical help
Keep the wound clean

rules.name: Eye Injury
rules.description: Eye injuries need careful treatment. Do NOT rub or press on the eye.
actions: Do NOT rub the eye
For chemicals: flush with clean water for 15-20 minutes
For objects: do NOT try to remove embedded objects
Cover the eye loosely with clean cloth
Seek medical help immediately
Do NOT apply pressure

rules.name: Severe Headache with Danger Signs
rules.description: Sudden severe headache with confusion may indicate stroke or brain hemorrhage.
actions: Call 108 immediately
Keep the patient still and quiet
Monitor consciousness level
Note time of onset
Do NOT give aspirin
Be ready to perform CPR

rules.name: Dehydration
rules.description: Dehydration needs fluid replacement. Severe cases can be dangerous.
actions: Give ORS (oral rehydration solution) or clean water with salt and sugar
Small, frequent sips — not large gulps
Rest in cool area
Monitor urine output
Seek medical help if no improvement in 2 hours
Watch for signs of shock

rules.name: Minor Symptoms - Low Urgency
rules.description: These symptoms are generally not emergencies but should be monitored.
actions: Rest and stay hydrated
Take over-the-counter pain relief if needed
Monitor symptoms for 24-48 hours
See a doctor if symptoms worsen
Clean and cover any wounds
Maintain good hygiene

rules.name: Breathing Difficulty Alone
rules.description: Any significant breathing difficulty is a potential emergency.
actions: Call 108 immediately
Help the person sit upright
Loosen tight clothing
If they have an inhaler, help them use it
Open windows for fresh air
Stay calm and reassuring
Be ready to perform CPR if breathing stops
